item.title: 15.1 Using the Resource Manager
item.description: 15.1 Using Resource Manager Resource Manager is a service that registers and runs Terraform Configuration as a function to automate OCI resource provisioning. Instead of installing Terraform on the client, you can register Terraform Configuration files in Resource Manager and run it with the OCI console or OCI CLI. The difference is that the Terraform CLI does not need to be installed separately, and the Terraform execution state is managed by the Resource Manager.

item.title: 1.1 Regions, Availability Domains
item.description: 1.1 Regions, Availability Domains Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) is hosted in Region and Availability Domain. Region is a geographical area and Availability Domain is a data center located in one region. A single Region consists of one or more Availability Domain. Availability domains are separated from each other so that they are not affected by defects at the same time or by defects in other Availability domains.Availability Domain is designed so that it does not affect other Availability domains because it does not share resources such as power, cooling and internal networks.

item.title: 1.2 Fault Domains
item.description: 1.2 Fault Domains A Fault Domain is a grouping of hardware and infrastructure within an Availability Domain. Each Availability Domain has three Fault Domains. Fault Domains ensure that compute instances are not distributed across one physical hardware within a single Availability Domain. Hardware failures or hardware maintenance within one Fault Domain do not affect other Fault Domains. When creating a new Compute instance, users can select a Fault Domain. If not selected by the user, the system automatically assigns them.

item.description: 6.5 Getting the Policy Concept IAM Policy IAM Policy is an access policy for OCI resources. A policy can generally be thought of as defining what grants a user group permission to a specific type of resource belonging to a specific compartment. Policy syntax All policies have the following syntax. Allow <subject> to <verb> <resource-type> in <location> where <conditions> For detailed syntax, please refer to OCI Documentation. https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/policysyntax.htm Policy General Format If the permissions for resources are defined through the policy below, all permissions are granted to the administrator when creating a tenancy, and general users and groups that do not apply a separate policy have no permissions at all.

item.title: 1.5 Bare Metal, Virtual Machine
item.description: 1.5 Bare Metal, Virtual Machine OCI offers both Bare Metal and Virtual Machine instances Bare Metal: Provides an environment where physical servers can be dedicated to a single user. By using the resources of the physical server directly and dedicatedly, we utilize 100% of the server resources to deliver high performance. Virtual Machine: Provides a computing environment through virtualization on a physical server. By going through a layer virtualized by the hypervisor, it offers relatively lower performance than bare metal.

item.title: 7.6 Uploading Files via CloudBerry Explorer
item.description: 7.6 Uploading Files via CloudBerry Explorer Object Storage provides its own API. It also provides an Amazon S3-compatible API. It is possible to upload large and large files through OCI CLI. Here we will try CloudBerry Explorer, which is a GUI tool available. Upload files via CloudBerry Explorer Object Storage provides its own API. It also provides an Amazon S3-compatible API, so you can use existing clients for S3 as it is.

item.title: 3.6.6 Unmounting Block Volume
item.description: 3.6.6 Unmounting Block Volume Unmount Connect to the Compute Instance with SSH. Update /etc/fstab Execute the sudo vi /etc/fstab command to delete /mnt/vol1, the volume to be unmounted, from the fstab file. sudo vi /etc/fstab Unmount sudo umount /mnt/vol1 Disconnect to Volume Open the navigation menu in the OCI console. Go to Compute > Instances. Click on the name of the target Instance you created earlier. On the Instance detail page, click Resources > Attached block volumes in the lower left corner.

item.title: 10.6 Checking the Load Balancer Connection
item.description: 10.6 Check Load Balancer Connection Open the navigation menu in the OCI console. Go to Networking » Load Balancers. Check the Public IP of the Load Balancer created earlier. Connect to LB’s Public IP through a browser. Refresh your browser. Since the LB distribution rule is set to Round Robin, you can see that they go one by one in order.

item.title: 7.7 Setting up an Archive via Lifecycle
item.description: 7.7 Setting up archives through lifecycle As one of the use cases of Object Storage, it is widely used for disk image backup and file backup. You are more likely to use a recent backup, but you are less likely to use a backup otherwise, but you often need to keep it for a long period of time, for example. item.title: 3.6.7 Deleting Block Volume
item.description: 3.6.7 Deleting Block Volume Caution Terminate the Block Volume and it will be completely deleted. Please note that this is not recoverable. Open the navigation menu in the OCI console. Go to Storage > Block Storage > Block Volumes. Click on the action icon next to Block Volume and then click on Terminate. Reconfirmation Once terminated, it cannot be recovered. If you still want to delete it, click Terminate. Terminate complete
